conversation.text: Hello. Do you need help?
Oh boy, do I! I want to make a chocolate bar, please
The first step requires you to melt 1/4 cup of coconut oil in a small sauce pan

conversation.text: Does it have to be coconut oil? Or can I use another kind of oil?
Cocoa butter would be an acceptable substitute.
evidence: you can use the same amount of cocoa butter instead.

conversation.text: Awesome, thanks! What is the next step?
Next, you want to sift 1/4 cup of cocoa powder in to your melted butter (or cocoa butter, if you used that instead).
evidence: Sift 1/4 cup (30g) of cocoa powder into the coconut oil.

conversation.text: What kind of cocoa powder is best?
Do you have cocoa nibs available?
No, I only have cocoa powder. But I have a cheap one and a fancy one.
You should use the most fancy one for this recipe, since it will give your chocolate bar a good taste :)
evidence: Use the highest quality, unsweetened cocoa powder you can find
poor-quality cocoa powder will result in poor-quality chocolate

conversation.text: Thanks! So I've done that. What do I do now?
Stir the mixture thoroughly until it's a nice, uniform mixture.
evidence: Use a wooden spoon to stir the two ingredients together until fully combined

conversation.text: Done! What should I do next?
Add 1/2 a tablespoon of honey, 1/2 a tablespoon of maple syrup to the sauce pan. Then, mix in 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Thoroughly mix until the mixture is uniform.
evidence: Add 1 ⁄2 tablespoons (22 ml) each of honey and maple syrup
before mixing in 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract.
Stir the mixture thoroughly until all the ingredients are fully combined

conversation.text: What should my mixture look like at this point?
It should be a rich, dark brown colour. The colour should be consistent all the way through, and there should be no chunks. Is that what yours looks like?
Yes, it looks exactly like that! Great :)
That's great to hear! So then next, you should remove the mixture from the heat and pour it in to your molds.
evidence: Remove the chocolate mixture from the heat and carefully pour into your selected molds.

conversation.text: Okay. What kind of mild shape should I use?

Any mold is fine! If you want to go traditional, simply line a baking tray and pour your mixture in to that - you can cut out the chocolate bars once the chocolate sets. Or, you could make some funky shapes with custom molds! What shape are you going for?
evidence: For a traditional chocolate bar shape, use a lined, square baking tray

conversation.text: Hmmm.... I have some star shaped molds, I think I'll go with those!
Stars sound great! Are you done that step?
Yes, I am! What should I do next?
You should transfer the chocolate mold in to the freezer and let it set for 15 minutes. Once cool, your chocolate should be done!
evidence: Carefully transfer your chocolate molds or baking sheet to the freezer and leave the bars to set for at least 15 minutes

conversation.text: Woohoo!! Chocolate! How do I store it, once it's set?
You can either keep it in the mold or remove them and store them in a plastic bag - as long as you keep them in the freezer, they should last about 1 month.
evidence: You can store the chocolate in its molds,
r remove them and keep your bars in a plastic bag in the freezer for around 1 month

recipe.title: How to Make a Chocolate Bar

procedure.summary: Melt 1/4 cup (50g) of coconut oil in a small saucepan.
procedure.description: Measure the coconut oil into a small saucepan and transfer it to the stove. Put the saucepan over a medium heat and let the coconut oil melt, stirring occasionally. While almost any coconut flavor will be disguised by the chocolate, you might be able to detect a few hints of it in the finished chocolate. If you don’t have coconut oil or don’t like the taste of it, you can use the same amount of cocoa butter instead.

procedure.summary: Sift 1/4 cup (30g) of cocoa powder into the coconut oil.
procedure.description: Measure out the cocoa powder and carefully sift it into the melted coconut oil, removing any lumps as you go. Use a wooden spoon to stir the two ingredients together until fully combined. Use the highest quality, unsweetened cocoa powder you can find when making your own chocolate. This will be the majority of the flavor in your bars, so poor-quality cocoa powder will result in poor-quality chocolate. Although it won’t be quite as good as chocolate made with cacao nibs, cocoa powder is considerably easier to find. Both methods will still create delicious homemade chocolate.

procedure.summary: Stir the sweeteners and vanilla extract into the chocolate mixture.
procedure.description: Add 1 ⁄2 tablespoons (22 ml) each of honey and maple syrup to the saucepan, before mixing in 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract. Stir the mixture thoroughly until all the ingredients are fully combined and the chocolate is homogenous. Run your measuring spoon or cup under hot water before using it to scoop up the honey or maple syrup. The residual heat will prevent them from sticking to the spoon and will make it much easier to get into the saucepan. The vanilla extract won’t add a strong vanilla flavor to your chocolate, it will only bring out the chocolatey-ness of the cocoa powder. If you have a particularly strong aversion to it, you can leave it out of the recipe.

Remove the chocolate mixture from the heat and carefully pour into your selected molds. For a traditional chocolate bar shape, use a lined, square baking tray that you can cut chocolate bars out of later. Specialty chocolate molds should be available from your local homeware or cooking store. Find ones with cool shapes for some unique chocolate creations.

procedure.summary: Freeze the chocolate for 15 minutes or until hardened.
procedure.description: Carefully transfer your chocolate molds or baking sheet to the freezer and leave the bars to set for at least 15 minutes. You can store the chocolate in its molds, or remove them and keep your bars in a plastic bag in the freezer for around 1 month.
